definitions.definition: comparative of  good : of a higher standard, or more suitable, pleasing, or effective than other things or people:
examples: He stood near the front to get a better view.

definitions.definition: If you are or get better after an illness or injury, you are healthy again:
examples: I hope you get better soon.
After the ceasefire, the situation in the capital got better.

definitions.definition: in a more suitable, pleasing, or satisfactory way, or to a greater degree:
examples: The next time he took the test, he was better prepared.

definitions.definition: to a greater degree, when used as the comparative of adjectives beginning with "good" or "well":
examples: She is better-looking (= more attractive) than her brother.

definitions.definition: used to say that a particular choice would be more satisfactory:
examples: Why don't you give her a call or, better still, go and see her?

definitions.definition: used to give advice or to make a threat:
examples: You'd better (= you should) go home now before the rain starts.
You would do better to bring the plants inside when the weather gets colder.

definitions.definition: something that is of a higher standard than something else:
examples: He ran the 100 metres in 9.91 seconds, and I have not seen better (= a faster result) this year.

definitions.definition: behaviour, work, or treatment that is more suitable, pleasing, or satisfactory:
examples: You shouldn't be so mean to your mother - she deserves better.

definitions.definition: people of a higher rank or social position than you:
examples: As children, we were taught not to argue with our elders and betters.
The organization was established to better conditions for the disabled.

definitions.definition: to improve your social position, often by getting a better job or education:
examples: He tried to better himself by taking evening classes.
